title: 114_hr335
content: The Act titled "Multinational Species Conservation Funds Reauthorization Act of 2015" amends and reauthorizes various conservation acts including the African Elephant Conservation Act, Rhinoceros and Tiger Conservation Act, Asian Elephant Conservation Act, and Great Ape Conservation Act. The amendments extend the authorization period from 2016 through 2020. The Great Ape Conservation Act of 2000 is amended to allow for multiyear grants to eligible persons for long-term conservation projects. Additionally, a panel of experts will be established within one year to review conservation efforts. The Great Ape Conservation Act of 2000 is amended to establish a panel of experts within one year to review conservation efforts and priorities, including representatives from foreign range states with expertise in great ape conservation. The Great Ape Conservation Act of 2000 is amended to establish a panel of experts to identify conservation needs and priorities, consider relevant conservation plans, and pay for meeting expenses. The Great Ape Conservation Act of 2000 is amended to increase the authorized funding amount to $150,000 and extend the authorization of appropriations from 2016 through 2020. SEC. 6. AMENDMENT AND REAUTHORIZATION OF MARINE TURTLE CONSERVATION ACT OF 2004. The Marine Turtle Conservation Act of 2004 is amended to include territories of the United States in various sections, defining "territory of the United States" and expanding the scope to include Puerto Rico, the United States Virgin Islands, Guam, American Samoa, the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, and any other U.S. territory or possession. The Marine Turtle Conservation Act of 2004 is amended to include territories of the United States in various sections, expanding the scope to include Puerto Rico, the United States Virgin Islands, Guam, American Samoa, the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, and any other U.S. territory or possession. Amendments include increasing the administrative expenses limitation to $150,000 and reauthorizing the Act for fiscal years 2016 through 2020.
